Data mining is the process of:

Extracting patterns from data

Discovering structure in complex datasets

text:
What is Artificial Intelligence?
Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to:

Computational systems that learn patterns from data to make predictions or decisions.




Artificial Intelligence is a broad field that includes:

Machine Learning (ML): Algorithms learn patterns from data.
Deep Learning: Neural networks with many layers.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
How AI Learns



Most common learning paradigms:
Supervised Learning:
Models are trained using labeled input-output pairs to predict outcomes for new data.
Unsupervised Learning:
Models that analyze and find hidden patterns, structures, or relationships in input data that is not labeled, categorized, or guided

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Supervised vs UnSupervised Learning



In Supervised learning we provide:

measurements (features)
diagnosis (labels)

The system learns:
How to predict diagnosis from measurements

This is the most relevant approach for biomarkers.




In UnSupervised learning we provide:

measurements

no diagnosis

The system tries to:

discover natural groups

identify hidden structure


Useful for discovering subgroups.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What Is a Model?


A model is:
A rule that combines variables to make predictions

Very simplified example:
If
- reaction time is slow
- pupil dilation is large
- HbO is reduced
Then
probability of disorder increases.


The computer learns this rule automatically.



Overfitting occurs when a model learns training data too well, capturing noise and random fluctuations rather than just the underlying patterns.
How we prevent Overfitting?
Using Cross-Validation: testing the model on Data it has never seen before.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Features Ranking



The Rank widget evaluates how informative each variable is for predicting the target. It:

scores each feature individually

orders variables from most to least informative



One common scoring method is Information Gain. Information Gain measures:

how much a variable reduces uncertainty (entropy) about the diagnosis

how much knowing that variable improves classification

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Models: Logistic Regression



The Logistic Regression widget is a simple and interpretable classification model to classify data into two groups. It:

estimates the probability of belonging to a group

combines variables linearly

works well when relationships are relatively simple




It is often a good first model to try because:

it is stable

it is easy to interpret

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Models: Random Forest


The Random Forest widget is a more flexible and powerful model.

It:

builds many decision trees

combines their predictions

handles complex and non-linear relationships




It is useful when:

variables interact with each other

patterns are not simple

prediction accuracy is the main goal

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Models: Support Vector Machine



The Support Vector Machine widget is a model that tries to find the best boundary between groups.
It:

separates groups with an optimal decision boundary
works well in high-dimensional data




It is often effective when:

groups overlap

there are many variables

the separation is subtle

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Models: Neural Network



The Neural Network widget is a model inspired by how biological neurons process information. It:

combines variables through multiple processing layers

can learn complex and non-linear patterns

adjusts internal connections to improve prediction




Neural networks are useful when:

relationships between variables are complex

patterns are not linear




However:

they are less interpretable than simpler models
they are more sensitive to overfitting

They are powerful tools, but should be used carefully in clinical research.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Test and Score



The Test and Score widget evaluates how well a model performs. This step is essential to avoid overfitting. It:

trains the model

tests it on unseen data

computes performance metrics



The widget reports measures such as:

accuracy

AUC

precision

recall

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Model Evaluation: Accuracy & Recall



Accuracy is the proportion of correctly classified individuals.

It answers:
How often is the model correct overall?

If accuracy is 0.80, the model correctly classifies 80 percent of participants.


Important limitation: If one group is much larger than the other,
accuracy can be misleading.



Recall, reflects sensitivity.

Of all the real disorder cases, how many did we correctly detect?

Low recall means:

many true cases were missed




Clinically, this relates to missed diagnoses.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Model Evaluation: Precision & F1 Score


Precision answers:
Of all the cases predicted as disorder, how many are truly disorder?

Low precision means:

many false positives




Clinically, this relates to false alarms.



F1 score combines precision and recall into a single number.


It answers:
Is the model good at detecting true cases while avoiding false alarms?


It is especially useful when:

classes are imbalanced

both false positives and false negatives matter

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Model Evaluation: AUC



AUC stands for Area Under the Curve.


It measures:
How well the model separates the two groups overall


It ranges from:

0.5 → random guessing

1.0 → perfect separation

AUC is useful because:

it is less sensitive to class imbalance

it reflects overall discriminative ability.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Model Evaluation: Why Multiple Metrics Matter
text:
Model Evaluation: Why Multiple Metrics Matter



No single number tells the whole story.


A clinically useful model should:

detect true cases

avoid false alarms

generalize to new patients




That is why we examine:
accuracy, recall, precision, F1 score, and AUC together.

Course Project: Biomarker Discovery


For this course you will complete an individual project.

Each student will receive a different dataset.


Each dataset contains:

several measured variables

Each row represents one participant.
Each column represents one variable.
One column contains the group label.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What is the pupil?



Why study the pupil:

visible & measurable
dynamically controlled
tightly linked to brain state

Pupillometry provides a fast, non-invasive window into autonomic and cognitive processes. What the pupil is:

the variable opening in the center of the iris
regulating the amount of light entering the eye

It functions like the aperture of a camera.








Two muscles control pupil size:

Sphincter pupillae → constriction
Dilator pupillae → dilation

These muscles are controlled by different branches of the autonomic nervous system.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Pupillary Control



Parasympathetic (ACh) pathway:

Retina
Pretectal nucleus
Edinger–Westphal nucleus
Oculomotor nerve (III)
Ciliary ganglion
Sphincter muscle

This mediates the pupillary light reflex (PLR).



Sympathetic (NE) pathway:

Hypothalamus
Spinal cord (ciliospinal center)
Superior cervical ganglion
Dilator muscle

This mediates pupil dilation in darkness, stress, and arousal.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text: Pupillary Control

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Central neuromodulation



Beyond reflexes, pupil size is influenced by:

noradrenergic signaling
cortical control systems
attention networks



The locus coeruleus:

regulates arousal
responds to novelty and uncertainty
influences sympathetic activity

Pupil dilation is correlated with LC activity.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Types of Pupillary phenomena



Pupil diameter changes reflect multiple processes:

light reflex & dark adaptation
cognitive load
emotional arousal
decision, surprise and novelty



Pupillary light reflex:

rapid constriction
latency around 200 ms
highly reliable
bilateral (direct and consensual)




Dark adaptation:

pupil dilates
sympathetic tone increases
under stress or arousal: dilation occurs even at constant luminance



Cognitive load
When task difficulty increases:

pupil dilates
even without luminance change

This is known as the task-evoked pupillary response.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Types of Pupillary phenomena



Working Memory

more items in working memory
larger pupil dilation
dilation scales with effort

Pupil size tracks mental workload.


During difficult decisions:

pupil dilation increases
uncertainty correlates with amplitude
surprise produces phasic dilation

This links pupil to decision-making models.



Emotionally salient stimuli:

increase pupil diameter
regardless of valence
scale with arousal intensity

Pupil reflects arousal, not emotional category.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text: Types of Pupillary phenomena

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
How pupillometry works



Modern pupillometry uses:

infrared illumination (850nm)
video-based eye tracking
automated pupil detection
sampling rate (>5Hz)

Typical steps:

record pupil diameter over time
detect and remove blinks
interpolate missing data
baseline correction
event-related averaging

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
How pupillometry works



Pupil is extremely sensitive to light. Therefore:

stimulus luminance must be controlled
screen brightness must be constant
visual properties must be standardized



Pupil responses:

begin ~200–500 ms after event
peak around 1–2 seconds
decay slowly

Faster than hemodynamic signals
but slower than EEG.



Tonic vs phasic pupil signals
Tonic level:

slow fluctuations
linked to sustained arousal

Phasic response:

rapid stimulus-locked dilation
linked to cognitive events

Both are informative.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Strengths and Weaknesses



Strengths

non-invasive
inexpensive
high temporal resolution
portable
suitable across lifespan
sensitive to arousal and cognitive load
compatible with many experimental paradigms




Limitations

highly sensitive to luminance
influenced by fatigue and circadian factors
affected by medication and autonomic state
low spatial specificity
reflects multiple overlapping processes

text: Self-check

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Why this course?



Psychology traditionally relies on:

behavior
self-report
clinical judgment

These tools are powerful, but limited.


Biomarkers promise objectivity, quantification, prediction, and personalization.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
The promise of biomarkers



Biomarkers are expected to:

reduce subjectivity
link behavior to biology
improve diagnosis and prognosis
guide treatment decisions
enable personalized approaches


Key question:
Do biomarkers actually deliver on these promises?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What do we mean by “biomarker”?
A widely accepted formal definition (NIH / FDA):

A biomarker is a defined characteristic that is measured as an indicator of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or responses to an intervention.




Key points embedded in the definition:

it is a measurement
it is an indicator, not a diagnosis
it is tied to a specific process or response




Immediate implications:

biomarkers are indirect
biomarkers are context-dependent
biomarkers are not explanatory by default

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What do we mean by “biomarker”?



Objective does not mean useful. A measure can be:

objective
precise
reproducible

And still be clinically useless.


Typical reasons:

large overlap between patients and controls
no added value over clinical assessment




Psychiatry and psychology still lack:

robust diagnostic biomarkers
clinically actionable predictors

Many proposed biomarkers:

are statistically significant
fail in real clinical settings

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
The core epistemological problem



Neurological, Psychiatric and Psychological phenomena are:

heterogeneous
dynamic
multidimensional


Biological systems reflect this complexity. As a result, one-to-one mappings
(one biomarker → one disorder) are rare.








graph LR
    B1[Biomarker A] --> D1[Disorder 1]
    B1 --> D2[Disorder 2]

    B2[Biomarker B] --> D1
    B2 --> D3[Disorder 3]

    B3[Biomarker C] --> D2
    B3 --> D3

    subgraph Biomarkers
        B1

        B3
    end

    subgraph Disorders
        D1

        D3

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Biomarkers are not “truth machines”



Biomarkers do not reveal truth directly. They are probabilistic signals.


Most biomarkers are correlates, not causes.
A biomarker may:

change with a disorder
track symptom severity
predict outcomes

Without explaining why. Biomarkers are not mechanisms.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Group-level vs individual-level thinking



Most biomarkers are discovered at the group level. Clinical decisions are made at the individual level.


Research question:

“Is there a difference between groups?”

Clinical question:

“Can I make a decision for this person?”

These are fundamentally different problems.



A biomarker can be:

statistically significant
and useless for deciding about a single patient



Biomarkers should be understood as:

decision-support tools
not decision-makers

They complement:

clinical judgment
contextual information

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What counts as a biomarker?



A biomarker can be:

molecular (genes, proteins, metabolites)
physiological (heart rate variability, cortisol)

neural (EEG features, imaging-derived measures)
behavioral (reaction times, eye movements)

computational (scores derived from multiple measures)



Biomarkers are not limited to biology at the molecular level.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What a biomarker is NOT



A biomarker is not:

a diagnosis
a symptom
a risk factor
an endophenotype
a clinical judgment
a mechanism



A biomarker can be a risk factor, but not all risk factors are biomarkers.



Mechanisms:

explain how a process works
imply causal structure



Endophenotypes:

are heritable traits
lie between genes and behavior
are relatively stable

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Context of Use (CoU)



A biomarker is only defined together with:

a target population
a clinical or research question

Without a Context of Use:

performance cannot be evaluated
usefulness cannot be judged




The same measured characteristic can be:

a biomarker in one context
irrelevant in another
misleading in a third

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Biomarkers are multidimensional objects



Biomarkers are often introduced as simple categories or lists. In reality, biomarkers vary along multiple dimensions.


Dimension 1: Biological Level

molecular
cellular
physiological
neural
behavioral




Lower-level does not mean:

more objective
more specific
more clinically useful

A genetic marker can be less useful than a behavioral one.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Dimension 2: Temporal stability


Biomarkers differ in how they change over time. Two broad classes:

trait-like biomarkers
state-dependent biomarkers


Trait biomarkers are:

relatively stable
minimally affected by context
often present before symptoms


Examples: genetic variants, structural brain features. They are often used for risk or susceptibility.




State biomarkers:

fluctuate over time
reflect current condition or context
are sensitive to environment and intervention


Examples: cortisol, EEG power, arousal





Biomarker
Key properties
Main limitation




Trait
Stable
Often weak predictors


State
Sensitive
Prone to bias

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Dimension 3: Specificity



Biomarkers differ in how specific they are.
Specificity can be:

disorder-specific
dimension-specific
transdiagnostic

Psychological/Psychiatric biomarkers are often transdiagnostic.


Many biomarkers in Psychology:

appear across multiple disorders
reflect shared processes




Mental disorders are:

heterogeneous
overlapping
not defined by single mechanisms

Therefore, biomarkers rarely show one-to-one mappings.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Dimension 4: Measurement context



Biomarkers depend on:

how they are measured
where they are measured
under which conditions



Laboratory vs real-world measures can differ substantially. A biomarker may work:

in controlled experimental settings
but fail in clinical practice




Measurement context directly affects:

reliability
validity
interpretability

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Dimension 5: Functional role



Biomarkers differ by what they are used for:

detection
prediction
monitoring
stratification

The same biomarker can serve different roles.



Example: EEG feature

diagnostic marker in one context
prognostic marker in another
monitoring marker in treatment studies

Function is not intrinsic to the measure.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Biomarker Evaluation



Biomarkers are not evaluated by intuition.
They are evaluated by:

measurement quality
error structure
decision consequences



A biomarker must be reliable before being useful.
Reliability refers to:

test-retest stability
inter-rater consistency
robustness across contexts




If a biomarker varies because of:

measurement noise
equipment differences
context instability

Then any observed association may be spurious. Reliability sets the upper limit of usefulness.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Biomarker Evaluation: Validity



Validity is contextual and it is not a single property. A biomarker can be:

valid for one purpose
invalid for another



Key forms of validity:

construct validity
criterion validity
predictive validity

Predictive validity is the most relevant for clinical use.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Error Structure


Every biomarker makes errors. There is no error-free biomarker.

When using a biomarker to classify or predict, there are 4 possible outcomes:

true positive
false positive
true negative
false negative

Every decision falls into one of these categories.








Disorder




Biomarker


Present


Absent






Positive


True positive


False positive




Negative


False negative


True negative

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Error Structure



A false positive occurs when:

the biomarker indicates a condition
but the condition is not present

Consequences:

unnecessary alarm
overdiagnosis
inappropriate intervention




A false negative occurs when:

the biomarker fails to detect a condition
that is actually present

Consequences:

missed diagnosis
delayed intervention
false reassurance




Which error is worse depends on context.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text: Error Structure

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Accuracy, Sensitivity and specificity



Accuracy:

Ability to detect a condition correctly

Sensitivity:

ability to detect a condition when it is present

Specificity:

ability to exclude a condition when it is absent



They describe different aspects of performance.



Increasing sensitivity often:

increases false positives

Increasing specificity often:

increases false negatives

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Confusion matrix


Confusion matrix and performance metrics for a biomarker






Predicted class


Performance metric




Actual class


Positive


Negative






Positive


True positive (TP)


False negative (FN)


Sensitivity TP / (TP + FN)




Negative

—

Negative predictive value TN / (TN + FN)


Accuracy (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN)





A confusion matrix, also known as error matrix is a specific table layout that allows visualization of the performance of a Biomarker.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Thresholds create errors



Most biomarkers require a threshold.


Changing the threshold:

changes sensitivity
changes specificity
changes error balance



ROC curves describe:

trade-offs between sensitivity and false positives
performance across thresholds

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Clinical utility is not accuracy
High accuracy alone is insufficient.
Clinical utility depends on:

consequences of errors
possibility to use across contexts
added value over clinical judgment

A slightly better biomarker can still be useless.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Functional classification of biomarkers
According to regulatory and clinical frameworks, biomarkers can be used as:

diagnostic
prognostic
predictive
monitoring
risk/suceptibility

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Diagnostic biomarkers


Diagnostic (classification) biomarkers are used to:

detect the presence of a condition
support or refine a diagnosis
identify subtypes of a condition


For diagnostic biomarkers:

false positives are especially harmful
specificity is critical
prevalence strongly affects usefulness




They answer the question:
Is this condition present?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Prognostic biomarkers


Prognostic biomarkers provide information about:

future course of a condition
likelihood of progression, relapse, or recovery


Prognostic biomarkers:

are independent of treatment
describe natural history
often work at the group level




They answer the question:
What is likely to happen over time?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Predictive biomarkers


Predictive biomarkers estimate:

likelihood of response to an intervention
likelihood of side effects


Predictive biomarkers are:

central to personalized medicine
highly attractive clinically
extremely difficult to validate

They require comparison across treatments.



They answer the question:
Will this treatment work for this person?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Monitoring biomarkers


Monitoring biomarkers are used to:

track changes over time
assess response or progression
support ongoing decisions


Examples:

physiological stress markers
EEG changes during treatment
behavioral performance over time




They answer the question:
Is the condition changing over time?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Risk/Susceptibility biomarkers


Risk biomarkers estimate:

vulnerability before onset
probability of developing a condition


Risk biomarkers:

generate many false positives
raise ethical concerns




They answer the question:
Who is at higher risk?

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Clinical reality is not the lab
text:
Clinical reality is not the lab


Clinical settings are characterized by:

time pressure
incomplete information
heterogeneous patients
high emotional stakes


Biomarkers must work under these conditions.



A biomarker is clinically applicable only if it:

improves decision-making
adds value beyond standard assessment
justifies its costs and risks
statistical significance is not enough.

In psychology and psychiatry:

clinical judgment remains central
biomarkers support, not replace, clinicians

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
“Positive” does not mean “certain”


Using biomarkers responsibly requires:

explaining uncertainty
communicating probabilities
avoiding deterministic language


Risk biomarkers raise special concerns:

labeling before symptoms
long-term psychological burden
unclear benefit of early knowledge




Responsible biomarker use requires:

clear context of use
awareness of error rates
integration with clinical data
continuous evaluation

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Neurovascular Coupling


Optical imaging methods do not measure neuronal activity directly. They measure vascular and metabolic changes that follow neural activity.

Neural signaling requires energy for:

action potentials
synaptic transmission
ion pumping
neurotransmitter recycling

All of these processes increase metabolic demand.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Neurovascular Unit



Neurons rely almost entirely on: glucose and oxygen. These are delivered by the vascular system. Neural activity therefore requires a local vascular response.


Neurovascular coupling refers to the set of mechanisms by which changes in neural activity lead to changes in:

cerebral blood flow (CBF)
blood volume
blood oxygenation



This coupling is local, regulated, and stimulus-dependent.



Neurovascular coupling is not controlled by neurons alone. It involves interactions between:

neurons
astrocytes
endothelial cells
smooth muscle cells

This is often referred to as the neuro-glio-vascular unit.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Neurovascular Mechanisms


There is not a single pathway linking neurons to vessels. Current models describe 3 main mechanisms:

direct neuronal signaling
astrocyte-mediated signaling
metabolic feedback signaling


These mechanisms act in parallel, not in isolation.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Mechanism 1: Direct neuronal signaling



Neurons can influence blood vessels directly.


This occurs through:

neurotransmitter release
neuromodulators
gaseous messengers (like nitric oxide, aka NO)




In this mechanism:

neural activity increases
neurons release vasoactive substances
nearby vessels dilate rapidly

This is often called a feedforward mechanism. It anticipates metabolic demand rather than reacting to it.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Properties of Direct Neuronal Signaling



Strengths

fast
spatially precise
tightly linked to synaptic activity




Limitations

not sufficient alone
does not encode metabolic state
varies across neuron types




This mechanism is responsible for the early vascular response.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Mechanism 2: Astrocyte-mediated signaling



Astrocytes:

sense synaptic activity
integrate signals over space and time
release vasoactive substances

They do not fire action potentials, but they actively regulate blood flow.








Typical sequence after synaptic activation:

glutamate activates astrocytic receptors
intracellular calcium rises
vasoactive signals are released (vasodilation)

This pathway is slower than direct neuronal signaling. Roles:

integrate and smooth fast neural fluctuations
contribute to spatial spread of vascular responses

This helps explain why vascular signals are broader than neural ones.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Mechanism 3: Metabolic feedback signaling



Neural activity alters local metabolism.
This leads to changes in:

oxygen levels
glucose consumption
carbon dioxide
pH

These metabolic changes influence vessel tone.



In this mechanism:

neural activity consumes oxygen
metabolic byproducts accumulate
vessels respond to restore balance

This is a feedback mechanism, not feedforward. It reflects actual energy use.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
The three mechanisms work together









Neurovascular coupling emerges from:

fast neuronal feedforward signaling
intermediate astrocytic integration
slower metabolic feedback







flowchart LR  
A[Neural activity] --> B[Neuronal signaling]  
A --> C[Astrocytic integration]  
A --> D[Metabolic changes]  
B --> E[Vascular response]  
C --> E  
D --> E

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Consequence for interpretation



Important implications:

signal amplitude ≠ firing rate
timing reflects vascular dynamics
spatial maps reflect integration




Despite its complexity:

coupling is reproducible
spatially organized
stimulus-dependent

This is why optical imaging works so well for mapping.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What does “intrinsic” mean?



Intrinsic signal optical imaging uses the brain’s own optical properties.



No dyes.

No fluorescent reporters.

No genetic indicators.

The signal emerges from:

hemoglobin absorption
blood volume changes
light scattering changes

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Why the visual cortex?



The visual cortex is the ideal model system because:

it has precise topographic organization
responses are stimulus-locked



Retinotopy is a functional property of several visual areas:

neighboring points in visual space
are represented by neighboring points in cortex

Different visual areas have a complete (almost) representation of the visual field.







flowchart LR  
A[Visual stimulus in left field] --> B[Right visual cortex activation]  
C[Stimulus moves upward] --> D[Activation shifts dorsally]







 
In ISI:

reflected light is recorded
The readout is a reflectance change over time.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Why reflectance changes



Hemoglobin absorbs light.


Oxygenated (OHb) and deoxygenated (RHb) hemoglobin:

have different absorption spectra
absorb differently at different wavelengths

Therefore: changes in oxygenation → changes in reflectance.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Wavelength matters



Different wavelengths emphasize different components.


Around 610-680 nm:

RHb absorbs strongly
active regions appear darker
signal correlates with increased HbR

Other wavelengths emphasize different dynamics.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Optical logic of ISI



Neural activation

increases oxygen consumption
transient increase in HbR
later increase in OHb



Optical consequence

reflectance decreases at HbR-sensitive wavelengths
spatially localized darkening
reproducible stimulus-locked maps

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Early and late components



The intrinsic signal has components:

initial dip (early oxygen extraction)
hyperemic response (increased blood flow)
post-stimulus undershoot

These reflect the three mechanisms of neurovascular coupling.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Mapping retinotopy with ISI



Typical paradigm:

moving bar stimulus
drifting grating
phase-encoded visual stimulation



The cortical response:

shifts smoothly
mirrors stimulus movement
produces continuous retinotopic maps



Video Video

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Mapping retinotopy with ISI



The retinotopic organization is so strong that you can even draw on the visual cortex.
In this experiment we tried to understand what is the stimulus shape from the activation pattern. As shown here: clear distinct activation patterns emerge after visual stimulation.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Beyond retinotopy



ISI has been used to map:

orientation columns (not in the mouse)
ocular dominance columns
somatosensory maps
auditory maps

It captures mesoscale cortical architecture.



ISI provides:

high spatial resolution (tens of micrometers)
large field of view
stable functional maps

This makes it ideal for cortical mapping in animals.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Strengths and Weaknesses



Strengths

no dyes required
stable across sessions
excellent for mapping cortex
strong signal-to-noise ratio
ideal for primary sensory cortices studies




Weaknesses

signal is slow (seconds)
reflects vascular integration (indirect signal)
cannot resolve spikes or fast oscillations
limited to surface cortex
requires surgical preparation
influenced by anesthesia

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
What is fNIRS?



Functional Near Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) is a non-invasive method that measures changes in:

OHb
RHb

through near-infrared (NIr) light transmitted across the scalp.








Biological tissue has an optical window approximately between:

700 nm and 900 nm

In this range:

light penetrates scalp and skull
hemoglobin absorbs selectively
water and lipids absorb less

This makes deep measurement possible.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
From reflectance to absorption



In ISI:

light hits cortex
reflectance changes are measured

In fNIRS:

light enters scalp
travels through tissue
is partially absorbed
exits at a detector


We measure changes in light attenuation (Absorbance).

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
The Beer-Lambert principle



The core idea:

the amount of light absorbed depends on
the concentration of absorbing molecules
and the path length



In fNIRS, the absorbing molecules are:

OHb
RHb



We estimate concentration changes from light attenuation.



OHb and RHb absorb light differently (see absorption coefficients). Using at least 2 wavelengths:

allows separation of OHb and RHb signals
enables estimation of relative concentration changes

This is called the modified Beer–Lambert law.


fNIRS measures changes in:

OHb and RHb
Total hemoglobin (THb = OHb + RHb)

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Typical activation pattern



During neural activation:

HbO increases
HbR decreases
blood volume increases


This pattern mirrors what we saw in ISI. The signal is vascular, not electrical.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Spatio-temporal Resolution



Spatial resolution:

centimeter-level spatial resolution
sensitivity to superficial cortex
no access deep brain structures.




Temporal resolution:

samples light at high frequency (tens of Hz)
but reflects slow vascular dynamics (seconds)


Temporal resolution is limited by physiology, not hardware.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Strengths of fNIRS



Advantages

non-invasive
silent (compared to fRMI)
portable
suitable for infants
usable in naturalistic tasks




Research relevance

social interaction studies (e.g. hyperscanning)
developmental research
clinical populations

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
fNIRS vs ISI



Intrinsic Signal Imaging

low invasive
reflectance
very high spatial resolution
animal models




fNIRS

non-invasive
absorption
low spatial resolution
human studies




Same physiology. Different optical constraints.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
The fNIRS device: basic components



An fNIRS system consists of:

light sources
light detectors
optodes placed on the scalp
acquisition and processing unit



Sources:

emit NIr light
typically at 2 wavelengths
are placed on the scalp




Detectors:

measure light intensity exiting tissue
are placed a few centimeters away from sources
are sensitive to small changes in intensity



An optode is a general term for:

a source optode (emits light)
a detector optode (collects light)

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Source-detector pairing



Optodes are arranged in structured arrays on the scalp.


A source and a detector form a channel. The distance between them is typically:

2.5 to 3.5 cm in adults
shorter in infants

This distance determines sampling depth.








The light path forms a curved trajectory called Banana-shaped sensitivity profile. Maximum sensitivity occurs approximately:

halfway between source and detector
at a depth of about half the separation distance



Scalp blood flow contributes strongly. To control for this, systems include Short (separation) channels:

short channels (8–10 mm distance)
mainly sensitive to superficial layers of the tissue

These are used to regress out scalp effects.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Source-detector pairing














fNIRS setup requires attention to:

hair interference
optode contact
ambient light contamination

Signal quality depends strongly on preparation.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text: Self-check

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Translational biomarkers



A translational biomarker is a measurement that:

quantifies a biological process linked to a disorder
is repeatable across sessions and sites
can be measured in both models and patients



Typical outputs you can bring into trials:

diagnostic / stratification feature
pharmacodynamic marker
mechanism-linked readout (helps interpret “why” a treatment works)




What to do (a practical checklist):

define the construct (what brain function you are indexing)
choose a readout with high reliability
test developmental sensitivity
test treatment sensitivity
report effect size + cross-validated prediction

A biomarker must be deployable, not only significant.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Neurodevelopmental disorders as critical period disorders
text:
Neurodevelopmental disorders as critical period disorders



A key theoretical proposal:
Some neurodevelopmental disorders may reflect disruptions of critical periods.
If maturation is altered during these windows:

circuit refinement may be incomplete or mistimed
long-term functional deficits emerge
later interventions may have reduced efficacy

This shifts focus from static deficit → altered developmental trajectory.



Why this matters clinically:
If disorders involve altered critical period timing, then we need biomarkers that:

detect dysfunction early
track developmental trajectories
are sensitive to maturation dynamics
can monitor reopening or rescue of plasticity

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Why visual cortex is ideal for critical period biomarkers
text:
Why visual cortex is ideal for critical period biomarkers



Primary visual cortex (V1) is one of the best-characterized critical period systems:

well-defined sensory input
precisely mapped circuitry
known developmental windows
measurable plasticity

Its maturation can be tracked quantitatively using:

ISI & fNIRS imaging
VEP

This makes V1 a natural testbed for developmental biomarkers.



If a disorder alters critical period timing or gain we expect to observe:

abnormal emergence of evoked responses
altered amplitude or tuning
reduced experience-dependent plasticity
persistent deficits into adulthood

Therefore, evoked V1 responses can serve as:

early detection markers
mechanistic indicators of circuit maturation
potential pharmacodynamic endpoints

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Why arousal is also linked to critical periods
text:
Why arousal is also linked to critical periods



Neuromodulators regulate plasticity:

acetylcholine
norepinephrine

These systems:

gate cortical responsiveness
modulate signal-to-noise
influence experience-dependent refinement

Arousal state is therefore not just behavioral, it shapes developmental plasticity.



If neuromodulatory tone is altered:

critical period dynamics may shift
plasticity thresholds may change
circuit refinement may be impaired

Pupil and HRV provide scalable readouts of these systems.
Thus arousal biomarkers may index a mechanism that directly impacts developmental timing.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
CDKL5 Deficiency Disorder (CDD)



CDKL5 Deficiency Disorder (CDD)


A severe developmental epileptic encephalopathy caused by loss-of-function variants in CDKL5



Cause - pathogenic variants in the CDKL5 gene (X-linked) - impacts neurodevelopmental signaling and circuit maturation
Core clinical picture - early-onset seizures (often in infancy) - global developmental delay and intellectual disability - motor impairment and hypotonia; often limited speech - frequent comorbidities: sleep, feeding, autonomic dysregulation
Why biomarkers matter - symptoms are heterogeneous and change over development - clinical trials need objective, repeatable functional endpoints beyond caregiver report

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
section: Why CDD is ideal for V1 + arousal biomarkers
text:
Why CDD is ideal for V1 + arousal biomarkers



CDD has strong rationale for visual cortex endpoints:

early circuit maturation is disrupted
sensory systems show measurable developmental trajectories
evoked responses can reveal when deficits emerge

This supports an early, longitudinal biomarker strategy.



CDD also fits an arousal biomarker strategy:

widespread neuromodulatory and autonomic involvement is plausible
arousal regulation can be measured without demanding tasks
passive measures support severe disability cohorts

This supports scalable endpoints for monitoring and stratification.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive

text:
Experiment: Early V1 impairment in CDKL5 mice


Intrinsic Optical Signal Imaging and VEPs  Reference 





Method


longitudinal transcranial IOS during development

repeated recordings across a developmental window

VEP recordings for validation

phenotype summarized with multi-feature classification (SVM)



Key results


developmental emergence of reduced evoked visual responses

deficit persists into later ages

early measures discriminate genotype with high accuracy

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
CDKL5: from model to patient



Preclinical evidence showed:

developmental impairment of V1 evoked responses
stable circuit-level deficit
strong genotype discrimination

But translational relevance requires confirmation in patients.



Key question:
Do individuals with CDKL5 show measurable visual evoked abnormalities?
And crucially:
Do physiological measures correlate with clinical severity?
If yes → the animal biomarker has clinical validity.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive

Visual Evoked Potentials and Clinical Severity in CDKL5  Reference 





Method


record VEP responses in individuals with CDKL5

quantify amplitude and latency parameters

assess relationship with standardized clinical severity scales



Key results


altered VEP responses compared to controls

physiological parameters correlate with clinical severity

stronger impairment associated with more severe phenotype





Translational significance


confirms that V1 dysfunction is present in patients

validates the mouse V1 phenotype as clinically relevant

supports evoked visual responses as a potential trial endpoint

text:
Creatine Transporter Deficiency (CTD)



Creatine Transporter Deficiency (CTD)


Loss of function in SLC6A8 → impaired creatine transport → neurodevelopmental impairment



Cause - pathogenic variants in SLC6A8 (X-linked) - reduced creatine availability in brain → altered energy buffering
Core clinical picture - global developmental delay and intellectual disability - speech and motor impairment; behavioral dysregulation - seizures can occur; autistic-like features are common
Why biomarkers matter - trials need objective endpoints that track brain function over time - a strong biomarker should be treatment-sensitive and repeatable

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive

Shared EEG network alterations (mouse ↔︎ patient)  Reference 





Method


EEG & ISI in CTD mouse model

EEG in individuals with CTD

oscillatory + network metrics

quantitative comparison



Key results


abnormal ISI and cortical oscillations in mice

overlapping EEG alterations in patients
objective cross-species signature

text:
From IOS to fNIRS



In CTD mice we identified:

robust V1 hemodynamic deficits

strong WT vs KO separation

longitudinal sensitivity

This established a reliable visual cortex biomarker.



Translational question:
How do we bring this to children?
Constraints:

non-invasive

tolerant to movement

feasible in pediatric populations

Solution: adopt fNIRS as human analog of IOS.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Why fNIRS for pediatric translation?



fNIRS measures:

changes in HbO
changes in HbR
total hemoglobin (THb)

It is:

portable

quiet

child-friendly

suitable for repeated sessions




Challenge:

hemodynamic signal is slow
children have limited attention span
traditional checkerboards are boring

Therefore, stimulus design becomes critical.

title: Metodi di Psicofisiologia e Neuroimaging nella Clinica e nelle Neuroscienze Cognitive
text:
Developing a child-friendly visual paradigm



Problem:
Standard reversing checkerboard blocks are:

repetitive

low engagement

difficult for long pediatric recordings

We needed a stimulus that was:

visually strong

engaging

compatible with block design




Solution:

embed checkerboard into animated cartoon content

maintain contrast reversals

preserve visual drive

increase compliance

Goal: maximize signal without losing attention.

Method


occipital fNIRS recordings

block design optimized for children

tested in typically developing cohort



Key results


robust visual hemodynamic response

high compliance and low dropout

strong THb and HbO modulation

reproducible across participants

text:
Visual fNIRS amplitude and autistic traits



In the typical population we observed:

variability in visual hemodynamic amplitude

stable individual differences

We then tested association with:

quantitative autistic traits




Key finding:

lower THb response amplitude

associated with higher autistic trait scores

Implication:
Visual cortical response amplitude may reflect
a dimensional neurodevelopmental phenotype.
